title: Brush scripted "Shape the Future!"
content: if it doesn't have to be exactely that font, you can definately find something very similar at [Fonthead](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516141544/http:/www.fonthead.com/) for a very fair price.
author: close

comments.content:
Iï¿½ve been through MyFonts, FontBook and a book called   
Schreibschriften (from Novum Press) without finding any   
exact matches...   
   
This is a tough one!
maybe a free font? dafont.com alike? Where is our Free type guru ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516141544im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)?

Ihave looked at DaFont in about 4 categories, at ThemeWorld, and 1001 Fonts. The only thing that made my pupils dilate was a ripoff of Excoffon's Choc, which at first resembled some of these characteristics. In other places RR's [Hauser Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516141544/http:/www.philsfonts.com/detail.html?sku=RR00007401P2) was a bit similar, but you said you need identical.   
   
You may have to consider that this is a custom font. As I frequently tell people who want me to ID hand-lettered fonts that look like anyone's lettering (not the work of a calligrapher or sign artist), these kinds of fonts are the easiest and cheapest kind to make,so an advertiser who wants a unique look can spend less than $50 and have a font made of any sample lettering. If this is from a commercial advertiser's promo material, that may be exactly what you are dealing with, I'm afraid.
